Introduction
A range of non-medical registered healthcare professionals can prescribe medicines for patients as either Independent or Supplementary Prescribers.

Currently registered nurses, pharmacists, optometrists, physiotherapists, chiropodists or podiatrists, radiographers (diagnostic and therapeutic) dieticians and midwives may undertake further professional training to qualify as non- medical prescribers.
The nationwide development of non-medical prescribing:
Can improve patient care without compromising patient safety;
Can make it easier and quicker for patients to get the medicines they need;
Increases patient choice in accessing medicines;
Makes better use of the skills of health professionals;
Contributes to the introduction of more flexible team working across the NHS.

The development of non-medical prescribing within the health service enables suitably trained healthcare professionals to enhance their roles and effectively use their skills and competencies to improve patient care in a range of settings involving:
management of long term conditions;
medicines management / medication review;
emergency/urgent care/unscheduled care;
mental health services;
services for non-registered patients e.g. homeless;
Palliative care.
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to:

Provide a framework to support appropriately qualified non-medical prescribers (nurses, midwives, pharmacists and allied healthcare professionals), to prescribe medicines safely and effectively within defined legislation and their scope of practice.

Provide guidance on implementation and management of non-medical prescribing, namely clinical governance arrangements, legal and ethical professional accountability within a framework of good practice
Definitions

Independent prescribers are practitioners responsible and accountable for the assessment of patients with previously undiagnosed or diagnosed conditions and for decisions about the clinical management required, including prescribing. There are restrictions on the prescribing of controlled drugs by some non-medical independent prescribers.
This is where a practitioner has successfully completed a prescribing course and has the annotation on the register, but has not prescribed regularly (less than 6 monthly).
Non-Medical Prescriber which includes independent prescribers and supplementary prescribers
Register of NMP's within the Trust who are permitted to prescribe and will identify their scope of practice
Legal class of medicines – Pharmacy Only. These can only be sold or supplied at a registered pharmacy premises by or under the supervision of a pharmacist

Legal class of medicines – Prescription only medicine. These cannot be administered or supplied unless one of the three types of instructions are in place:- a signed prescription from an appropriately qualified health practitioner , this can be a doctor dentist or other independent or supplementary prescriber a signed Patient specific Direction (PSD) a Patient Group Direction (PGD)

A supplementary prescriber is a practitioner who prescribes within an agreed patient specific clinical management plan (CMP), agreed in partnership by a supplementary prescriber with a doctor or dentist. The clinical management plan must relate to the named patient and to that patients' specific conditions to be managed by the supplementary prescriber and must be included in the patients' clinical record. It is recommended that CMP' are reviewed formally at appropriate time intervals, usually within 12 months
Electronic prescribing and medicines administration system e.g. Chemocare, Metavision,Wellsky.

Chief Executive
Acts as the organisation's accountable officer and has overall responsibility for:
Ensuring Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Nursing Officer

Ensuring the MSE Strategy for non-medical prescribing is congruent with the Trust's objectives and is delivered by the senior professional leads. They may delegate operational management as NMP lead to an appropriate senior professional lead.
Liaising with the Site Directors of Nursing, ensure that there is policy compliance and that NMP's are working safely and effectively within their responsible areas.
Site Directors of Nursing / Deputy Directors of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and NMPs are practicing safely and effectively;
Ensuring any escalated NMP issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Associate Directors of Nursing/Matrons/Head of Departments
Ensuring that there is a correlation between a desire to undertake the course and the NMP role and the need for the role within the service and subsequent approval to undertake the NMP course;
Ensuring that that there is policy compliance within the areas that they are responsible for and that NMPs are prescribing safely and effectively;
Ensuring that any escalated NMP issues involving professions they oversee are managed appropriated and are escalated up to Site Directors of Nursing/Chief Pharmacists if necessary.
Line Managers
Ensuring staff in prescribing training are released to attend study days and practice placement activities in accordance with the Higher Education Institute's requirements;

Conducting an annual appraisal (minimum) to ensure the prescribing role is being undertaken safely and effectively & CPD relevant to the prescribing role has been documented. Consider the NMPs self - reflection documentation (See appendix 2) as evidence to support their practice during the appraisal process and ensure that the NMP has reviewed / updated as appropriate, their scope of practice document annually.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for non-medical prescribing across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
Maintaining a central register of all non-medical staff qualified and authorised to prescribe within the Trust;
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with Pharmacy Heads of Departments that NMP's within their responsible area are working safely and effectively within their responsible area.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates responsibility for delivery of mse-wide NMP strategy to the designated site pharmacy head of department for workforce.
Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Responsible for
Ensuring that Pharmacist NMP's on their respective sites are working safely and effectively within their responsible area;
Escalating any concerns with non-medical prescribing to Chief Pharmacist or Site Director of Nursing as appropriate;
Ensuring NMP's have access to expert pharmaceutical advice when required;
Providing appropriate support to the NMP site leads.
Site Nursing NMP leads
Monitoring, receiving and maintaining appropriate documentation for NMPs on their site;
Communicating to the Chief Pharmacist any amendments to the NMP Trust central register;
Organising and coordinating the NMP learning workshops;
Escalating to the MSE NMP strategy sub group any concerns around non- medical prescribing within the Trust
Provide support to the NMPs on each site by helping to guide them through the approval process and after registration.
Site Pharmacy NMP leads
Escalating to the MSE NMP strategy sub group any concerns around non- medical prescribing within the Trust;
Liaising with the site Nursing NMP leads to ensure that appropriate documentation is maintained;
Provide support to the NMPs on each site by helping to guide them through the approval process and after registration.
Clinical Lead (within relevant specialty)
Supporting the day to day prescribing activities of the NMP e.g. professional guidance, mentoring, developing skills, identifying CPD opportunities.
Working with, supporting and approve specific actions to regularly evaluate the safety, effectiveness, appropriateness and acceptability of non-medical prescribers in their specialty.
Independent and supplementary prescribers
Adhering to the details in this policy and following the steps outlined in Appendix 2 in order to be admitted to the Trust NMP register and commence prescribing;
Complying with the Royal Pharmaceutical Society's : A Competency Framework for All Prescribers (2016);
Ensuring that they have on their professional register the annotation as non-medical prescriber (either Independent or Supplementary);
Being responsible and accountable for their individual practice and prescribing only within their scope of practice;
Being aware that prescribing outside of their scope of practice may be subject to disciplinary action;
Recognising their own limitations /competencies with respect to their level of practice or expertise and referring patients to the appropriate medical doctor for assessment or prescribing;
Putting in place, together with their clinical lead, specific actions to regularly evaluate the safety, effectiveness, appropriateness and acceptability of their prescribing;
Demonstrating continuing professional development in areas relevant to
their prescribing practice.
Non-Medical Prescribing Course Application

To ensure appropriate use of education funds and release of staff for study days / practice placements, all applicants must submit via email to the site NMP lead for consideration at the NMP strategy sub group the following:
The reasons why they want to undertake the course;
Name of their line manager together with evidence of the line manager's approval.
This will ensure the module application requirements are met, that there is adequate service need and that there will be support during / post qualification.

NMP modules undertaken as part of a degree pathway do not entitle the individual to automatically become a NMP, unless there is a current or planned need within their role. This is agreed in writing with the prospective student and a note added into their personnel file by their line manager.
All non-medical prescribers must ensure their job description specifically recognises the prescribing role. Any issues relating to job description must be addressed at this point by the line manager.
If the job description does not reflect the prescribing role, addendum to Job description: Non-medical prescriber needs to be completed (Appendix 5).
A copy of the addendum to Job description needs to be sent to the site NMP lead and a copy kept in the staff's personnel file.
Appendix 1 provides a step wise approach to ‘How to apply become a NMP'.
Non-medical Prescriber Registration and approval to practice
On successful completion of the NMP course the professional's regulatory body will be notified via the Higher Education Institution.
It is the individual's responsibility to ensure that their qualification has been registered with their professional regulatory body.
Prescribing prior to this is an offence under the Human Medicines Regulations 2012, and will result in disciplinary action.
New NMPs will contact via email the Nursing NMP lead on their site to inform them of their successful completion of the course.
The NMP will receive a letter from the site lead detailing instructions on the next steps to be followed for addition to NMP register and subsequent practicing as a NMP (see Appendix 2).
All NMPs must submit a specimen signature to Pharmacy as detailed on Appendix 3.
All NMPs must complete a Scope of Practice document (Appendix 4) which must be scanned to the appropriate site nursing NMP lead.
NMPs can only commence prescribing once they have received confirmation back from pharmacy that they are on the Trust NMP register and scanned their scope of practice as detailed in 6.7.
Legal Liability of Prescribing
The Trust is held vicariously liable for the actions of a NMP only when a NMP has:
completed an approved programme;
completed the steps outlined in Appendix 2;
prescribes within their scope of practice and within the boundaries of professional code of conduct;
the Trusts permission by virtue of being on the Trust NMP register.
Failure to comply with the Trust's prescribing policy may result in disciplinary action being taken in line with Trust policy.
The Trust policy on accepting Hospitality / gifts from drug companies must be adhered to and the site specific pharmacy department can provide guidance/ advice on this.
Prescribing and Prescriptions
Refer to the Trust Prescribing Policy (or equivalent). It must be followed by all prescribers regardless of profession.

NMPs must only prescribe within their scope of practice and following current legislation and professional standards. It is the responsibility of the individual practitioner to remain up to date with relevant practice / legislative changes.

A NMP can only issue a prescription for a patient whom they have personally assessed and cannot issue a prescription if asked to do so by another healthcare professional, unless they have personally assessed the patient.
NMPs must only prescribe within the MSE medication formulary (or site equivalent).

Supplementary prescribers may prescribe any medicine (including controlled drugs); within the framework of a patient-specific clinical management plan (CMP), which has been agreed with a doctor.The CMP is the foundation stone of supplementary prescribing. Before supplementary prescribing can take place, it is obligatory for an agreed CMP to be in place (written or electronic) relating to a named patient and to that patient's specific condition(s) to be managed by the supplementary prescriber. This can include Controlled Drugs and unlicensed medicines for any medical condition, provided these are prescribed within the terms of the CMP.
When using a paper based prescription (inpatient drug chart, outpatient prescription drug administration chart) the prescriber must annotate with letters ‘NMP'.

For sites using Wellsky (formerly JAC) ePMA (commonly referred to as ePrescribing), NMP's must complete the appropriate training (Appendix 7) and upon completion of the training they will be able to prescribe on the ePMA system. The account in ePMA will be defined as NMP and when a medicine is prescribed this will be displayed as ‘Prescribed by NMP'

When issuing an FP10 prescription, they must contain the professional registration number of the prescriber. FP10 prescription pads are the property of the Trust and the prescriber must adhere to MSEPO-21005 FP10 Prescription Policy and Procedures.

For prescribing unlicensed medicines, practitioners must follow MSBPO-18017 Unlicensed Medicines Policy. Prescribers must be aware they take full responsibility and accountability. Patients must be informed of the unlicensed status.
Off label prescribing (indication outside of the UK licence) is permitted; ensure that the Trust Prescribing of Medicines Policy (or equivalent) is followed.

Different aspects of the prescribing, dispensing and administration process should be separated and undertaken by different members of the team except in exceptional circumstances i.e. there is a separation of prescribing from drug administration.

Pharmacists can undertake the verification/clinical screening of a prescribed medication at the same time as prescribing. Ideally a second pharmacist will clinically check the prescription. However where this is not possible the prescribing pharmacist will self-check their own prescribing and verify/screen the prescription with a suitable time delay.

It is good practice for pharmacist independent or supplementary prescribers to have no involvement in the dispensing process of prescriptions written by themselves. In exceptional circumstances where this may compromise patient care then this can happen but steps must be taken to ensure appropriate governance is taken.
Items that are prescribed and that need to be administered immediately by the Non-Medical Prescriber must be checked independently by a second registered nurse of pharmacist prior to administration.
Any adverse reactions must be managed as per Trust's Prescribing of Medicines Policy or equivalent.
The requirements for record keeping should be as detailed in the Trust's Prescribing of Medicines policy or equivalent.
It is the responsibility of non-medical prescribers to report any incidents or near misses relating to their practice, using the Trust's incident reporting system.
New Trust staff with existing prescribing qualifications

It is the responsibility of the line manager to ensure any new members of staff (who arrive to the Trust with prescribing qualifications) provide evidence of safe prescribing practice within the clinical role they are being employed to undertake; and that they meet the requirements outlined in Appendix 2.This will include the NMP providing evidence of their qualification and registration status of a currently practicing NMP or if practice has lapsed when they last practiced as an NMP.
If practice has lapsed refer to section 10 below.
A completed scope of practice document (Appendix 4) and sample signature form ( Appendix 3) must be completed and supplied to the nursing NMP site lead and Chief Pharmacist as appropriate.
Lapsed prescribing practice
This is where a practitioner has successfully completed a prescribing course and has the annotation on the register, but has not prescribed regularly.

If the practitioner has not prescribed for 6 months the line manager/clinical lead must be involved in assessing the practitioner's return to prescribing using the Lapsed NMP practice form (Appendix 8).

Where electronic prescribing systems are available, reports will be generated quarterly for the NMP strategy sub-group for consideration in identifying any practitioner not actively prescribing. Their line manager / clinical lead will be notified after 6 months in order to support return to prescribing practice if appropriate.
The NMP must not prescribe until this Lapsed NMP practice form is satisfactorily completed the NMP and they are signed off (in writing) as being safe to recommence prescribing.
If NMP is working at a site with electronic prescribing, the NMP will be suspended from the system, as a prescriber, until they have been signed off as being safe to recommence prescribing.
The line manager and clinical lead are expected to support a period of professional development to a point where the clinical lead is satisfied with the NMP practitioner's competency level.
Site lead nursing NMP lead will provide feedback on any ‘non-active' prescribers and progress in returning to practice will be reviewed at each NMP strategy sub-group meeting.
Training Requirements

All new non-medical prescribers are made aware of the policy through the application process to attend a non-medical prescribing course. No specific training within the Trust is required as accredited training is provided through the Higher Education Institute.
For sites with Wellsky ePMA, once qualified NMP's must complete eLearning – Wellsky ePrescribing for Prescribers – before obtaining an account.

When a nurse/pharmacist with an existing account qualifies as an NMP, the training eLearning – Wellsky ePrescribing for Prescribers must be completed and a request must be submitted to the ePMA team to change their account permissions to include prescribing (see Appendix 7).
Continuing Professional Development (CPD) and Revalidation
It is the responsibility of all NMPs to keep up to date with clinical and professional developments as well as with best prescribing practice and management of conditions for which they prescribe.

Self-refection forms (Appendix 6) can be completed and used for CPD, appraisals and as part of the revalidation process for the NMP. The Trust recommendation is that a minimum of one per year is completed or 3 every 3 years if a nurse undertaking their revalidation

In order to remain on the Trust NMP register and continue to prescribe, NMPs are required to participate in at least one Non-medical prescribing workshop per annum. These will be conducted on all sites every 2 months and will be
advertised in advance. Participants may choose to join remotely or attend at any site.

NMPs must review their scope of practice document (Appendix 4) with their clinical lead and/or line Manager on an annual basis and re- submit to the appropriate NMP site nursing site lead when there has been any amendments who keeps a scanned record of the scope of practice.

Congratulations on achieving your Non-Medical Prescribing qualification. Once you have had this annotated against your registration (NMC etc.) you are required to complete the following process:

You will receive an email back from pharmacy confirming that your name has been added onto the Trust NMP register. You must not prescribe in any circumstance until this has been done. Failure to adhere may result in disciplinary action taken against you.

data.text: The post holder is prescribing as a non-medical prescriber as part of their duties consistent with their clinical role, supported by their line manager and clinical colleagues. The post holder must:
Adhere to the relevant regulatory frameworks in relation to Standards of Practice and the Medicines Act and local Prescribing Standards.
Ensure that they provide appropriate, evidence based, safe and cost effective prescribing to their patients/clients at all times.
Adhere to their professional code of conduct.
Be individually and professionally accountable for their prescribing decisions, including actions and omissions, and cannot delegate this accountability to any other person.
Be professionally obliged to act only within and not beyond the boundaries of their knowledge and competence.
Introduce themselves by name and role (nurse / pharmacist / midwife) at the start of any consultation.
Be able to recognise and deal with pressures (e.g. from the pharmaceutical industry, patients, their families or colleagues) that might result in inappropriate prescribing
Ensure that they have adequate professional indemnity insurance.

Attend regular CPD and maintain in their portfolio of evidence, including at least attendance at one trust NMP workshop meetings per year and to complete 3 self- reflection practice documents per year.
